qas.question: What do subsidized funds do to the cost of an education at BYU?

context: Students attending BYU are required to follow an honor code, which mandates behavior in line with <a4_0>LDS teachings<a4_0/> such as academic honesty, adherence to dress and grooming standards, and abstinence from extramarital sex and from the consumption of <a9_0>drugs and alcohol<a9_0/>. Many students (<a6_0>88<a6_0/> percent of men, <a2_0><a7_0>33<a7_0/> percent<a2_0/> of women) <b10_0><b11_0>either delay enrollment or take a hiatus from their studies <a0_0>to <b12_0><b13_0>serve as Mormon missionaries<b13_0/><b12_0/><b11_0/><a0_0/>.<b10_0/> (Men typically serve for <a3_0>two-years<a3_0/>, while women serve for 18 months.) An education at BYU is also <a8_0><b14_0>less expensive<a8_0/> than at similar private universities<b14_0/>, since "a significant portion" of the cost of operating the university is subsidized by <a1_0><a5_0>the church's tithing funds<a5_0/><a1_0/>.
